I love this song!
Most people feel that it's coming from depression and a will to harm others by your personal pain. I however feel that this is something much more encouraging and uplifting!
He's singing of self sacrifice for someone or others he cares about.  He knows that if he's going to bring someone down even to the last breath, he'd rather die.  He is putting his life out there, willing to live, to the last drop of blood, for the life of the other.
When he says "Innocence is gone and what was right is wrong", he realises that his wrongdoings and misunderstandings of what is right in life have been shown for the falsehood in which they live. How can he live with his nature if his nature is so twisted?  Another thought is that he sees himself as the "one who knows" and the "right thing" (looking the other way, or "just living" regardless of the internal destruction to others) is now the "wrong thing".

I have so much more I could pick out of this song, but I'd need a lot more space... ;)

Scarecrows are used to ward off birds like crows and ravens, both birds symbolizing evil. comment_38:
Some people are saying this song is about suicide and cutting, but I disagree. I think this song is the battle cry of sorts for friends or partners to rise up and protect the ones they loveâ¦and I think it uses a Biblical allusion to convey that message.

I have to preface this by saying that this song is ambiguous. It could mean completely different things to different people, and thatâs part of what makes it so personal.

I think the song alludes to the Crucifiction to call friends out to sacrifice for one another. In a way, itâs a cry to be more like Jesus in his willingness to sacrifice despite the pain. (A couple of the band members are Mormon, so this meaning is certainly possible.)

Itâs not going to make much sense unless we look right at the lyrics, so letâs dive right in.

1) âIâm bleeding out / So if the last thing that I do / Is bring you down / Iâll bleed out for you / So I bare my skin / And I count my sins / And I close my eyes / And I take it in / Iâm bleeding out / Iâm bleeding out for you, for you.â

This is the cry of Jesus âbleeding outâ on the cross as the âlast thingâ he does (while in the flesh, of course). He âbare[s]â his skin to the lashings and âcounts his sinsâ (which are exactly none).  This could also apply to an individual whoâs âbleeding out,â or sacrificing something, âfor you,â his friend. He exposes himself when he âbare[s]â his skin and âcounts his sins,â ready to âtake it inâ to save his friend.

2) âWhen the day has come / That Iâve lost my way around / And the seasons stop and hide beneath the ground / When the sky turns gray / And everything is screaming / I will reach inside / Just to find my heart is beating.â

Yet another Imagine Dragons song with a post-apocalyptic feel. This also feels like how a depressed individual might view the world, so I can see why people may misinterpret the song as one related to depression and self-injury. This could also be how Jesus felt on the cross (with everyone laughing or âscreamingâ at him and the seasons and sky fading, like they know what it means that his end is near). Itâs a little extreme of an interpretation, but it could fit. What would fit better yet is a more human explanation. When the individual feels âlostâ and feels like all is coming to an end, he will remember what he holds dear to him, in his âheart,â and keep up the struggle.

3) âOh, you tell me to hold on / Oh, you tell me to hold on / But innocence is gone / And what was right is wrong.â

This feels like Jesus crying out on the cross, as well, doing what is ârightâ in saving us by doing what is âwrongâ in being crucified despite lacking sin.

4) âWhen the hour is nigh / And hopelessness is sinking in / And the wolves all cry / To fill the night with hollering / When your eyes are red / And emptiness is all you know / With the darkness fed / I will be your scarecrowâ

Youâve found my favorite part! Iâm a sucker for the word ânigh.â Anyway, I think this is the strongest part of the song. In continuation with the crucifiction allusion, this seems like the part where Jesus is about to die (âthe hour is nighâ) and the âwolves,â or people who condemned him, âfill the night with holleringâ and someone in the crowd, possibly Mary, has âredâ eyes from crying. Still, Jesus hangs on the cross, similar to a âscarecrowâ in both his physical position and in keeping the darkness from the crops, keeping Satan from his followers. Isnât that a gorgeous comparison? I get really geeked out when unusual metaphors fit so perfectly. The lines would also fit for an individual who sacrifices for his friend, who feels âhopelessâ and âempty.â He intends to sacrifice himself to keep the âdarknessâ from taking hold of his friend.

What should we take away from this, then? I think we should be better friends. I hope youâre never in a desperate situation where you must chose whether to save your friend or yourself, though the song seems to feel clearly about which is more important. The lyrics should be applied to the smaller things. Perhaps if your friend needs to discuss the pains in his/her life, you should sacrifice your time. If your friend needs a hug, you should sacrifice your personal space. If your friend needs a tub of ice cream and a couple distracting flicks to get over a tough breakup, you should sacrifice your money. Most importantly, this song seems adamant that if your friend suffers from depression, you should sacrifice all you can (in good conscience, of course) to help.

For interpretations of other songs, check out my blog, toriphelps.wordpress.com

comment_43:
I get the feeling that this song is about a person who is utterly in love with another... but that person uses them endlessly. Their lover simply takes and never gives. And whenever the person contemplates leaving the unhealthy relationship, their boy/girlfriend convinces them to stay.

"I'm bleeding out
Said if the last thing that I do"

Bleeding out - reminds me of taking a bullet for someone. Essentially the main person/character that this song is about (the MC) is in a relationship where he'd do anything for his significant other. Even bleed out - to death even. Because that would be the last thing he would do.

"Is to bring you down
I'll bleed out for you"

Again, he mentions that he would suffer, and practically die for his significant other. He also states that he would never make the other person suffer and always take the brunt of the consequences. The man has a slightly skewed view on what a proper relationship is.

"So I bear my skin
And I count my sins
And I close my eyes
And I take it in"

I almost picture someone getting whipped to represent a metaphor. By baring his skin (or back) to get punished. This person gets himself ready to take the pain and suffering. Baring his skin to voluntarily get beat up. By counting his sins, he tries to remember all the things he did to deserve this, justifying his pain. Maybe he thinks he isn't good enough, wasn't nice enough, didn't do enough for his significant other. He closes his eyes to make the pain not seem as bad as it actually is, and takes the pain as best he could. 

"And I'm bleeding out
I'm bleeding out for you (for you)"

The man takes the pain for his lover because everything he does is for them. Rather than in a relationship, he's like a faithful servant that is oblivious to his own unhealthy relationship.

"When the day has come
But I've lost my way around"

One day he comes to the realization that his relationship isn't what it once was. His love is different, foreign, and he's lost as to what happened to their relationship. He's utterly dependent on his lover although he is constantly being used. 

"And the seasons stop and hide beneath the ground
When the sky turns gray
And everything is screaming
I will reach inside
Just to find my heart is beating"

Basically, he beings to stop noticing his surroundings and time passes, the seasons pass but he doesn't notice. He is too caught up in his unhealthy relationship. The sky is gray, and it's almost like he is depressed, but he doesn't realize it. His entire being is screaming because he is suffering but he continues to ignore it. He continues to believe that he is in a healthy relationship and that he would do anything for his lover. That's why he reaches deep inside of himself to remind himself why he loves his lover.

"You tell me to hold on
Oh you tell me to hold on"

After his bouts of negative contemplation (gray skies and screaming), there are moments of clarity. Where he considers ending his relationship. But whenever he brings up the topic, his lover convinces him to stay in the relationship. To 'hold on' to what they have.

"But innocence is gone
And what was right is wrong"

His argument is that their innocent relationship has been long gone. That they once had a healthy relationship that was right... Until she took advantage of it and made it poisonous. 

"'Cause I'm bleeding out
Said if the last thing that I do
Is to bring you down"

He manages to be convinced that he should stay in the relationship. He states that he's hurting really bad but he did promise that he would never hurt his lover- so he agrees to stay in the relationship. His lover manages to guilt trip him to stay.

"I'll bleed out for you
So I bear my skin
And I count my sins
And I close my eyes
And I take it in
And I'm bleeding out
I'm bleeding out for you (for you)"

And the cycle continues. He sacrifices his well being and practically living as a servant to his lover.

"When the hour is nigh
And hopelessness is sinking in"

Sometimes at night he stays up and realizes the endless cycle of his suffering and stupidity for staying in the relationship.

"And the wolves all cry
To feel they're not worth hollering"

This reminds me of Call of the Wild. The freedom from imprisonment. But he has a fear of loneliness, and he isn't sure if freedom is worth it. OR- wolves could reference to the fact that he may leave the relationship, but who is to know that he won't enter another abusive relationship?

"When your eyes are red
And emptiness is all you know"

His eyes are red, from crying or from his suffering. He is used to the emptiness of loving but never being loved in return.

"With the darkness fed
I will be your scarecrow"

He's empty, without a heart. And he is willing to work. A scarecrow scares away crows and birds from the crops all day and night. Essentially, it serves as a metaphor to explain although he's is empty on the inside and full of darkness, he will continue to do things for the sake of his lover.

"You tell me to hold on
Oh you tell me to hold on"

Once again, his lover's argument for convincing him to stay.

"But innocence is gone
And what was right is wrong"

Once again his argument for leaving.

"'Cause I'm bleeding out
Said if the last thing that I do
Is to bring you down
I'll bleed out for you"

But then he remembers his promise to never hurt his lover and he gives up on his argument to leave and decides to stay.

"So I bear my skin
And I count my sins
And I close my eyes
And I take it in
And I'm bleeding out
I'm bleeding out for you (for you)"

The suffering continues.

"I'm bleeding out for you (for you)
I'm bleeding out for you (for you)
I'm bleeding out for you (for you)
